The "Classical" Prince-Dormand 13 stage combined order 7 and 8 Runge-Kutta scheme
See: High order embedded Runge-Kutta formulae, by P.J.Prince and J.R.Dormand,
 Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics, vol. 7, 1981, pages 67-75

85-digit coefficients obtained from Peter Stone's website. The exact rational coefficients
are also available from the same website and also in the github of Julia's SciML package.

Coefficients for the free 5th order interpolant obtained from Bogacki and Shampine (1990). The error estimate
weights for the 5th order interpolant, derived by the authors, are also included here.

I managed to derive an 18-stage 7th order interpolant for the DP8(7) pair using the four (4)
additional stages by Tsitouras et al (1997) and applying the Nystrom Transformation algorithm (Sharp and Fine, 1992)
on the resulting 18-stage RK (7,8) pair. 

Tsitouras et al (1997) derived a two-step O(h9) interpolant for DP8(7). They added three (3) additional stages
to the original 13 stages (and the 14th FSAL stage) to furnish an 8th order solution at the midpoint.
Thus, in the interval [xn, xn+1], the values yn, y'n; yn+1/2, y'n+1/2 (18th stage); and yn+1 and y'n+1 are now available.

A GRKN (7,8) pair is obtained by applying the Nystrom Transformation algorithm. This directly solves general second order differential equations
of the form y" = f(t, y, y'). If the 2nd derivative function is independent of y, then the resulting 2nd order ODE is equivalent to a
first order ODE by the change of variables, u=y', leading to u'=f(t,u).

Hence, on the interval [xn, xn+1], 9 values are thus available: yn, y'n, y"n; yn+1/2, y'n+1/2, y"n+1/2; and yn+1, y'n+1, y"n+1. An 8th order
interpolant is thus available for y. Differentiating the interpolant yields a 7th order interpolant for u=y'. Thus, the basis polynomials
bi7(sigma) for the stages k1 to k18 are available and finally derived.

The 7th order interpolant has one stage more than the minimum required - a total of 17 stages is the minimum required for an RK (7,8) pair
to have a 7th order interpolant. But the additional 18th stage makes the interpolant more accurate since the solution and derivative
values at the midpoint are 8th-order accurate as well as those at xn and xn+1.

References
--------
http://www.peterstone.name/Maplepgs/Maple/nmthds/RKcoeff/Runge_Kutta_schemes/RK8/RKcoeff8d_1.pdf
https://github.com/SciML/DiffEqDevTools.jl/blob/master/src/ode_tableaus.jl
Papageorgiou, G. & Tsitouras, Charalampos. (1997). Continuous extensions to high order Runge-Kutta methods. International Journal of Computer Mathematics - IJCM. 65. 273-291. 10.1080/00207169708804616. Retrieved from the ResearchGate website https://www.researchgate.net/publication/242926976_Continuous_extensions_to_high_order_Runge-Kutta_methods
P. Bogacki and L.F. Shampine. (1990). INTERPOLATING HIGH-ORDER RUNGE-KUTTA FORMULAS. Retrieved from https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/82504311.pdf
P.W. Sharp, J.M. Fine, A contrast of direct and transformed Nystr√∂m pairs, Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics, Volume 42, Issue 3, 1992, Pages 293-308, ISSN 0377-0427, https://doi.org/10.1016/0377-0427(92)90082-9. (https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0377042792900829)

c[1] = 1/18
c[2] = 1/12
c[3] = 1/8
c[4] = 5/16
c[5] = 3/8
c[6] = 59/400
c[7] = 93/200
c[8] = 5490023248 / 9719169821
c[9] = 13/20
c[10] = 30992876149296355 / 33518267164510641
c[11] = 1
c[12] = 1

# 14th stage evaluation is the slope at the right endpoint, the 1st stage of the next step

c[13] = 1

# Error estimate weights for the interpolant. This will restrict the step-size of the RK pair in order to ensure
# that the interpolation error is of the same order as the RK pair. This involves the 14th stage.

ei[0] = -0.0007317617907963511238
ei[1] = 0
ei[2] = 0
ei[3] = 0
ei[4] = 0

ei[11] = 0.0152880857182437849692
ei[12] = -0.0168659048183292252571
ei[13] = 0.0001657774977047690953

# The basis polynomials are 6th-degree, but still 5th order accurate when interpolating the solution.

# Four (4) additional stages for a 7th order interpolant for a total of 18 stages.
# 15th stage

c[14] = 1/5
